items.title: In Rural Minnesota, a 70-Acre Lab for Sustainable Living
items.abstract: Imagine a house that can go without heating for two days in a bitterly cold winter. Or a greenhouse with what may be the largest hot-air solar panel array in North America.

items.title: I.B.M. Research Points to Circuits That Mimic the Brain’s Design
items.abstract: Researchers at the computer giant said Thursday that they had developed a fluidic electronic system that mimics the way the brain works.

items.title: To Fight Gridlock, Los Angeles Synchronizes Every Red Light
items.abstract: With the number of cars on the road continuing to rise, boosters of the city’s new synchronized traffic system admit it may not be enough to prevent gridlock from worsening.

items.title: New York City Unveils Parking App Pilot Program
items.abstract: Parking on New York City streets can be frustrating, but the city Transportation Department will try to alleviate the problem using a smartphone app.

items.title: A City That Turns Garbage Into Energy Copes With a Shortage
items.abstract: Oslo, where roughly half the city and most of its schools are heated by burning garbage, is forced to import garbage to supply its waste-to-energy incinerating plants.

items.title: Cities to Untangle Traffic Snarls, With Help From Alphabet Unit
items.abstract: A federal Transportation Department partnership with the Alphabet unit Sidewalk Labs will put the power of Google’s data into a traffic management system.

items.title: A Small Palace as Family Home in Coastal Suburban Lisbon
items.abstract: Fourteen miles east of the Portuguese capital, a fanciful five-bedroom, stone-covered house dating from 1899 combines the elegant and the rustic.

items.title: Haze Returns to Mexico City, Where Not Driving Is Hardly an Option
items.abstract: Officials are focusing on automobile emissions in their battle to improve air quality, but residents point to a sprawling city where a car is necessary.

items.title: A 23-Foot-Tall Air Purifier Gets a Tryout in Smoggy Beijing
items.abstract: The co-designer Daan Roosegaarde considers the Smog Free Tower a first step in environmental awareness and significant in urban entrepreneurship.

items.title: Technology Is Monitoring the Urban Landscape
items.abstract: Much technical change in American cities will involve monitoring, which can make life easier but poses troubling questions about privacy and control.

items.title: In High-Tech Cities, No More Potholes, but What About Privacy?
items.abstract: Cities, including some far from the coasts, are vying to use technology to guide services. But the race toward “smart cities” is raising privacy worries.

items.title: Boeing’s 737 Max: 1960s Design, 1990s Computing Power and Paper Manuals
items.abstract: The Boeing jet that crashed twice in five months relied on decades-old systems and left pilots without some common safety features.
keywords: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

items.title: Boeing Built Deadly Assumptions Into 737 Max, Blind to a Late Design Change
items.abstract: A system that doomed two flights was expected to engage only rarely and originally used two sensors. Critical decisions were based on those factors even when they no longer applied, employees said.
keywords: Boeing 737 Max Groundings and Safety Concerns (2019)

items.title: Smile, Your City Is Watching You
items.abstract: Local governments must protect your privacy as they turn to “smart city” technology.

items.title: I’m an Engineer, and I’m Not Buying Into ‘Smart’ Cities
items.abstract: Sensor-equipped garbage cans sound cool, but someone still has to take out the trash.

items.title: With Sensors on Streets, France Takes Aim at ‘Noise From Hell’
items.abstract: The French authorities are installing “sound radars” in some cities to detect and photograph vehicles making excessive noise, which they say is a public health hazard.

items.title: Can Technology Help Cities Manage Curbs Better?
items.abstract: We’re asking our streets and sidewalks to do more and more. Start-ups are trying to help with curbside management tools — but will cities rise to the challenge?

items.title: Five Ways to Prevent the Next Sandy
items.abstract: When Hurricane Sandy deluged New York City, leaders promised bold action. Ten years later, it’s fair to ask: What, exactly, has been done?
